text:
I was asking <@UBS7QANF3>. If the book was that good and had alpha I'd keep to myself as I'm selfish.

"Good" gambling books are rare as horse shit.

There are plenty of gambling ebooks on Amazon.

I don't think I use any material from gambling books in what I do. I think I might use calculations from the wizard of odds website but that should be common knowledge to professionals these days.

text: I think keeping any notion of perceived alpha to yourself is a really bad idea. Firstly, ideas are cheap, it's execution that is expensive - I can literally give you 100 ideas now that would each take you a month to backtest (I certainly haven't tested them, they're just really obvious based on experience, articles, books, etc.), so what you might see as me "sharing a gift" would actually be encumbering you with > 8 years of grind to get through, so you're still going to have to think for yourself and prioritise. Secondly, if you keep secrets from me, I'll keep secrets from you - human beings are social animals, and IME the more you give, the more you get - this applies to this game, career mentoring, friendships, relationships, entrepreneurship, every aspect of my life I've ever touched. If your experience is different to that, I'm actually genuinely sad for you. Finally, if you are not interested in sharing or hearing about ideas _why are you here on this slack_? :smile:

text: It isn't. It's sincere. Example: I trade a little pre-off horses. I know horses well as somebody who watches _a lot_ of racing. If somebody said to me "what ideas do you have for inplay?" I could happily list (and have listed in pubs, ask <@UBS7QANF3>!), ideas about how I'd break that problem down. I don't see the problem: I'm never going to implement it, they're just ideas.

text: It's like when I was doing consultancy at startups and asked to sign NDAs: I have enough of my own ideas to build, I don't have a need to build yours or protect those things I've thought about I know I'll never build.

text: Would or wouldn’t? I think most people would not. It demonstrably did not hurt Benter to publish. In fact, it probably drew people with ideas towards him. And if writing the paper where an exact methodology is described is not enough to sink his ability to make money, that suggests ideas are cheap and implementation is the hard bit. In that world view, what does it mean to point to a book with tens of ideas and say “this is a good place to start”? Not a lot that’s negative, to my mind.

text: I will never explicitly ask anybody to give me their inside line, but I do think most people are over protective of ideas. We all grew up hearing stories of patents not filed in time, and the like… just don’t think all that applies the way the most paranoid fear. But everyone do what’s comfortable for them, I guess.

text: Surely the Benter edge stems from that hard earned data though (at least the raw edge from pricing). You could scrape racing post and apply the same statistical technique to build a model but I'd imagine it would perform poorly. I've enough confidence in that opinion to have so far not bothered doing it but who knows, maybe I've been sitting on a gold mine all this time. I know the HK racing setup is very different to racing in other countries, but I'm just talking in general - freely available generic data versus specifically formulated data requiring hundreds of man hours to get hold of is always going to lose out.

elements.text: Surely the Benter edge stems from that hard earned data though (at least the raw edge from pricing). I know the HK racing setup is very different to racing in other countries, but I'm just talking in general - freely available generic data versus specifically formulated data requiring hundreds of man hours to get hold of is always going to lose out.

text: HK is special, that’s true. And there is value in proprietary data, but I suspect lots of value in just creating 2nd or 3rd order derivatives of the data that is publicly available, you don’t need horsemen watching tape for hours on end. Most people do not - and actually do not know how to - use basic form book data properly. Some people make money regardless. To expand on this point might tread into an idea I have for sharing some ideas December I’ve been thinking about. I’ll leave it there for now… :)

text:
Let me just drag this back to the original book that <@UBS7QANF3> referenced.
> In an engaging, colloquial style, Cotton argues that market-inspired “superminds” are likely to be very effective compared with other orchestration mechanisms in the domain of microprediction. He presents an ambitious yet practical alternative to the expensive “artisan” data science that currently drains money from firms. Challenging the machine learning revolution and exposing a contradiction at its heart, he offers engineers a new liberty: no longer reliant on quantitative experts, they are free to create intelligent applications using general-purpose application programming interfaces (APIs) and libraries. He describes work underway to encourage this approach, one that he says might someday prove to be as valuable to businesses—and society at large—as the internet.
That is one _hell_ of a claim It also sounds quite philosophical, but I note the <https://github.com/microprediction/home|GH repo> has pointers to code implementations. How practical is it <@UBS7QANF3>? How hand wavey?

text: Too early to tell. I share your reservations and I'm also a bit unsure how you properly incentivise people to share their predictions (if I understand the entire concept correctly)

text: Sharing is a way to make you examine what you're thinking (nobody wants to recommend something stupid) and only a fraction of people who look at an idea will make anything, the rest add to the pool. And if you help someone to be a winner, they'll be more likely to recommend the game to other people and most of those will be losers.   Aaaand the more you give, the more you get in return.

text:
What do people think of this comment?

_"“I want to be very clear with government, any further tax rises now will not only slam the breaks on growth for our sector, but it will threaten jobs and completely derail horse racing."_

<https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2024/oct/14/shares-uk-gambling-firms-fall-higher-taxes-budget-2024>

user_profile.real_name: Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon
user_profile.name: fcmisc

elements.text: What do people think of this comment?
"“I want to be very clear with government, any further tax rises now will not only slam the breaks on growth for our sector, but it will threaten jobs and completely derail horse racing."

text: Horse racing and bookmaking did fine when regulations were much tighter and taxation (passed onto customer via betting tax), was higher. The levels being discussed are lower than those in much of the World, and where gambling operates albeit in different conditions. There is clearly limited appetite in the UK for where the industry is now, in terms of addiction, profitability (see mild to extreme discomfort every time Denise Coates’ accounts get reported), or prevalence on TV and in high street.

elements.text: Horse racing and bookmaking did fine when regulations were much tighter and taxation (passed onto customer via betting tax), was higher. The levels being discussed are lower than those in much of the World, and where gambling operates albeit in different conditions. There is clearly limited appetite in the UK for where the industry is now, in terms of addiction, profitability (see mild to extreme discomfort every time Denise Coates’ accounts get reported), or prevalence on TV and in high street.

text: All depends on the detail. Industry opinion is that if you make online casinos more expensive through higher taxation, instead of limiting growth in that area you’ll see operators move out of sports betting as customer acquisition costs rise on casino operations rise - more certain returns lie there, so make that the focus. I’m not sure I buy that, TBH. The sector just hates regulation, taxation, everything, so will cry about loss of jobs the moment anyone comes near them.

text: Given that online slots players are six times more likely to be problem gamblers than sports bettors though, I suspect government want to be quite targeted about impact.
